newsitem.title: GERMANY: FOCUS-UAL tops up Airbus order.
newsitem.headline: FOCUS-UAL tops up Airbus order.

text.p: United Airlines, the U.S. carrier, said on Friday that it had ordered seven additional aeroplanes from European manufacturer Airbus Industrie and was also negotiating with Boeing over three more wide-body jets.
In a statement issued in Germany, UAL said it would add four Airbus A319s and three A320s to an order of 24 A319s placed last August in a deal valued at $900 million at the time.
"The first new aircraft will be delivered in the next few months," UAL said. The company's Frankfurt office could not give any information on price terms for the extra planes.

United also said it was in negotiations with Boeing, U.S. rival to the European Airbus consortium, over buying three large jets to add to 27 wide-body jets -- 19 747-400s, six 757s and two 777s -- it also ordered last summer.
UAL said that the orders were part of a general modernisation for which it would invest some $5.2 billion by the year 2000 and retire 111 ageing aircraft from its fleet of 564 planes.
The spending breakdown would be $2.3 billion this year, $1.7 billion next year and $1.2 billion in 1999, with strong profits in recent years creating the conditions for investment, UAL said.
The company said that the fleet rejuvenation would save $100 million in maintenance costs after 2000.

The Airbus consortium groups France's Ste Nationale Industrielle Aerospatiale, British Aerospace Plc, Daimler-Benz Aerospace AG, a unit of Daimler-Benz AG and Construcciones Aeronauticas SA (CASA) of Spain.
